column3: ",Purchasing,,415-554-6743,,,"The San Francisco Department of Public Health (DPH) Zuckerberg General Hospital is currently seeking a software application that will generate a “Choice List” for patients of services that accept their insurance and meet their specific needs, and will meet Medi-Cal regulations by setting up an interface with Epic that allows for clinical documents and patient demographic information to be accessed and attached to referrals that can be electronically sent to qualified providers.

column1: **Vendor’s proposed solution must be published as an available application in the Epic App Orchard at the time of bid response.**
For details, please review the attached RFP document and Zip files (A1, A2, A3) containing required forms and important supporting documentation.
For questions, please contact Ron Rossi at ron.rossi@sfdph.org.
THE LETTER OF INTENT IS MANDATORY AND REQUIRED IN ORDER TO SUBMIT PROPOSALS.
ONLY VENDORS THAT SUBMITTED AN LOI BY THE DUE DATE CAN E-MAIL
QUESTIONS CONCERNING THE SPECIFICS OF THE PROGRAM.

IT: Medical Coding and Billing, Health Records, Hospital Software Bids,MD,Health Data Utility Frame Work,State/Local,,Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene,Today ,Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene,https://emma.maryland.gov/page.aspx/en/bpm/process_manage_extranet/45083,"BPM029777
column3: ",Purchasing,,410-767-6500,,,"The Maryland Health Care Commission (MHCC) seeks a Contractor (also referred to as Offeror herein) to develop a Health Data Utility (HDU) Framework – A Guide to Implementation (Framework) that will assist Maryland, including government, health care organizations, software developers, and health information exchange (HIE) organizations to implement an HDU.  The purpose of the HDU Framework is to guide (1) the collection, aggregation, and analysis of clinical information, public health data, and health administrative and operations data to assist providers in care delivery and public health leaders in the evaluation of interventions and health equity; (2) the communication of data from public health officials and providers to advance disease control and health equity; and (3) the enhancement and acceleration of interoperability of health information throughout the State and across states.  The HDU Framework will serve as the basis for fully implementing the HDU in Maryland and a model for developing HDUs in other states."

The Texas Health and Human Services Commission (HHSC) is an agency within the Texas Health and Human Services (HHS) system. The Procurement and Contracting Services (PCS) division of HHSC administers solicitations for HHS.

HHSC PCS is seeking competitive bids to establish Contract(s) to join an existing web based direct care employer registry system (“Enhanced System”)**.  The Enhanced System would serve multiple purposes a direct care employer registry, a job matching portal specific to direct care positions, and a learning management and resource library.
Procurement Schedule - All Times are Central Time
Responses to Questions or Clarifications - Addendum posted on the ESBD

Teichert Construction intends to work cooperatively with all qualified firms seeking work on this project, including but not limited to breaking out contract work items into economically feasible units to increase overall MBE/WBE participation. Plans and specifications are available from the municipality listed above and the Teichert?s Roseville Estimating office. For assistance obtaining or regarding the plans and specifications, please contact the listed Estimator.

100% Payment and Performance Bonds for subcontractors are required. Teichert will pay bond premium up to 2%. Insurance Waiver of subrogation also required. However, certified MBE/WBE's are encouraged to contact Teichert and request assistance if they are unable to meet Teichert's standard bonding or insurance requirements. MBE/WBE's also are encouraged to contact Teichert for assistance in obtaining lines of credit, equipment, supplies, materials or related assistance or services. Subcontractor, Supplier and Trucker quotes must be valid, at minimum, for the award period stated in the contract documents. Please note that this is a prevailing wage project and Teichert Construction is Union signatory. Subcontractors will be subject to the terms and conditions of Teichert's subcontract and safety documents available at www.teichert.com/for-subcontractors.cfm. Submission of a bid to Teichert will confirm that you have reviewed and accepted Teichert's subcontract form. Conditions or exceptions in Subcontractor?s quote are expressly rejected unless accepted in writing prior to bid. Subcontractor scopes and supplier quotes are required 24 hours prior to bid. Additional information and or assistance to MBE/WBE's available from: *** All Subcontractor Quotes must have the Department of Industrial Relations # to be ACCEPTED ***
A. Teichert & Son, Inc. dba Teichert Construc

Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids,CT,Airfield Paint Markings,State/Local,,"Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, Connecticut","Jun 10, 2022","Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, Connecticut",https://flytweed.com/,"Bids
column3: ",Purchasing,,203-466-8833,,,"LEGAL NOTCE INVITATION FOR BIDS Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport Airfield Paint Markings Specifications and Bid Documents for the Airfield Painting at the Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport for the Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, are expected to be available for examination at the offices of the Airport Manager, Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport, Administration Building 155 Burr Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06512 on Thursday, May 19, 2022. Interested parties may obtain copies of the bid proposal package by calling Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport at telephone no. (203) 466-8833, Ext. 1002 between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., or by visiting the Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport website at www.flytweed.com on Thursday May 19, 2022. Sealed bids will be received at the above address until 2:30 p.m. on Friday June 10, 2022. They will then be opened and read. Awards will not be made to any bidder whose name appears on a debarred list from performing contracts for the Federal Government, the State of Connecticut or any agency of the foregoing. The proposed contract is under and subject to Executive Order 11246 of September 24, 1965 and to the Equal Opportunity Clause. The Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, in accordance with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (78 Stat. 252, 42 U.S.C. 2000d to 2000d-4) and Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, Department of Transportation, Office of the Secretary, Part 21, Non-discrimination in Federally-assisted programs of the Department of Transportation, hereby notifies all bidders or offerors that it will affirmatively ensure that any contract entered into pursuant to this advertisement, disadvantaged business enterprises will be afforded full and fair opportunity to submit bids in response to this invitation and will not be discriminated against on the grounds of race, color or national origin in consideration for an award. The requirements of 49 CFR Part 26, Participation by Disadvantaged Business Enterprises in Department of Transportation Financial Assistance Programs, apply to this contract. The Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority encourages participation by all firms qualifying under this solicitation regardless of business size or ownership. All contracts and subcontracts that result from this solicitation incorporate by reference the provisions of 29 CFR part 201, the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), with the same force and effect as if given in full text. The FLSA sets minimum wage, overtime pay, recordkeeping, and child labor standards for full and part-time workers."

column3: ",Purchasing Department,,404-679-1600,cdonley@tcsg.edu,,"The Technical College System of Georgia is accepting sealed bids on behalf of West Georgia Technical College (Owner) for Sealing and Striping Campus Parking Lots in strict conformity with the project plans, bidding documents and contract documents associated with this project. Wet Georgia Technical College is located at 176 Murphy Campus Blvd, Waco, Georgia 30182. This project has been posted as a sealed, electronic bid event within the Team Georgia Marketplace system. The project plans are attached to the bid event. Review the document titled Invitation to Bid located on the Georgia Procurement Registry bid notice and the Team Georgia Marketplace bid event for more information about the Mandatory Pre-bid Conference. MANDATORY PREBID CONFERENCE: West Georgia Technical College will be hosting a Mandatory Pre-bid Conference at 10:00 a.m. EST on June 15th, 2022 to discuss the scope of work associated with this project. Review the Mandatory Pre-bid Conference document attached to the GPR Bid Notice for more details. For technical assistance with registration or accessing your existing profile, contact the DOAS Customer Service Help Desk by phone at 404-657-6000 or by email at ProcurementHelp@doas.ga.gov, Monday through Friday, from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, excluding State Holidays or any other day state offices are closed such as furlough days or closings in response to inclement weather."

column1: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids,GA,Traffic Pavement Marking Services,State/Local,,"East Point, Georgia","Jun 23, 2022","East Point, Georgia",https://ssl.doas.state.ga.us/gpr/eventDetails?eSourceNumber=21660902022-1795&sourceSystemType=doas,"2022-1795
column3: ",Purchasing Director,,404-270-7207,tdjones@eastpointcity.org,,"Electronic bids will be received by the City of East Point Purchasing Department, until Thursday, June 23, 2022, at 3:30 pm. The bids will be publicly opened and read aloud. Late bids will not be accepted. The times and locations of the services will be on an “as needed” project basis for the life of the contract. The City or its representative shall notify the Contractor, orally or in writing as to the time, location and type of services required for each assignment. Since this is an annual contract and the need for services are not known at the time of execution, the City does not guarantee any minimum or maximum amounts. All work to be performed shall be completed Monday through Friday during normal working hours unless the City is notified by the Contractor and receives approval at least 24 hours prior to a change in the work hours. “Overtime” is not expected. There will not be a mandatory pre-bid conference for this project. The Contractor shall perform and carry out Pavement Marking Services for items outlined in the Bid Price Schedule, and as specified herein in accordance with the Georgia Department of Transportation Standard Specifications, 2013 Edition, sections 652 thru 659. The location for this Work / Project is: [East Point, Georgia 30344] The Selected Provider shall furnish all materials, equipment, tools, supplies, and labor necessary to complete the required services as described herein and to the specifications as directed including all incidentals as determined by the East Point Public Works Director or his representative. All bidder’s questions shall be directed to the City of East Point, via email to tdjones@eastpointcity.org no later than 12:00 PM, Friday, June 10, 2022. The formal solicitation package may be obtained by visiting the City’s web site located at City of East Point Procurement (ionwave.net) . Solicitation documents cannot be obtained in person from the City nor by mail, email, fax, or courier service."

column1: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids,GA,Muralist,State/Local,,"Canton, Georgia","Jun 10, 2022","Canton, Georgia",https://ssl.doas.state.ga.us/gpr/eventDetails?eSourceNumber=226611466114-22-RFP-0517&sourceSystemType=doas,"66114-22-RFP-0517
column3: ",Purchasing Director,,770-704-1500,kristin.norton@cantonga.gov,,"The City of Canton/Canton Cultural Arts Commission is seeking an artist or artist team to submit renderings for a new public art mural project to be installed on a wall along the back of Village Laundry, 401 Marietta Road, overlooking Harmon Park in Canton’s historic Sunnyside neighborhood. Proposals are encouraged from artists and/or artist teams who have experience in creating large scale work on exterior walls. Award will be determined after submission – and additional information may be requested. Submissions may be emailed, mailed or hand delivered to Canton City Hall at 110 Academy Street, Canton Georgia. Please visit https://www.cantonga.gov/government/departments/finance/rfps-bids for complete details."

column1: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids,GA,Striping,State/Local,,"Oglethorpe County, Georgia","Jun 16, 2022","Oglethorpe County, Georgia",https://ssl.doas.state.ga.us/gpr/eventDetails?eSourceNumber=2270910OC2021LMIGTSPLOSTSTRIPING&sourceSystemType=doas,"OC2021LMIGTSPLOSTSTR
column3: ",Purchasing,,706-743-5270,aforrester@oglethorpecountyga.gov,,"GEORGIA PROCUREMENT REGISTRY INVITATION FOR BIDS ADVERTISEMENT OGLETHORPE COUNTY, GEORGIA FISCAL YEAR 2022 GDOT LMIG, TSPLOST, & STRIPING PROJECT Sealed proposals will be received by the Board of Commissioners of Oglethorpe County, P. O. Box 261, 105 Union Point Road, Lexington, Georgia 30648, until 1:00 PM on Wed. June 16, 2022. All bids will be publicly opened and read aloud. Project Description: Project will consist of Traffic control, deep patching, OGI Leveling, Resurfacing, Milling Bridge Ends, Grading Complete, Full Depth Reclamation, G.A.B., Installing raised thermoplastic rumble strips, Shoulder building, grassing, and Re-striping on various County Roads. Mrs. Amy Forrester, Oglethorpe County Clerk will be Oglethorpe County’s contact person for acquiring bid packages. Mrs. Forrester’s phone number at the Oglethorpe County Commissioners Office is (706)743-5270. Blank bid forms may be picked up at the Oglethorpe County Commissioners Office at 105 Union Point Road, Lexington, Georgia. Contract Time: All work is to be accomplished within 6 months of the Project Notice-To-Proceed-Date to be issued by Oglethorpe County. Payment: Contractor to submit monthly pay request to Oglethorpe County and Oglethorpe County agrees to review and process pay requests within 30 days from receipt. A total of ten percent (10%) of progress payments, if applicable, will be retained until final acceptance by Oglethorpe County has occurred. Successful bidder will strictly adhere to all Current Georgia DOT Regulations, Current Standards and Specifications, all Current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices guidelines, and all requirements included in the Project Agreement between Oglethorpe County and the successful bidder. Oglethorpe County reserves the right to reject any or all bid package documents received. All questions should be Emailed to Barry L. Wood, WOOD ENVIRONMENT & INFRASTRUCTURE SERVICES, INC. @ barry.wood2@woodplc.com"

column1: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids,GA,Master Arts & Cultural Plan,State/Local,,"Norcross, Georgia","Jun 3, 2022","Norcross, Georgia",https://ssl.doas.state.ga.us/gpr/eventDetails?eSourceNumber=2266780NPAC22-01&sourceSystemType=doas,"NPAC22-01
column3: ",Purchasing,,770-448-2122,shayla.alexis@Norcrossga.net,,"The City of Norcross is soliciting highly qualified consulting firms or individual consultants to provide professional services for the “Norcross Master Arts and Cultural Plan.” The consulting firm/consultant is expected to perform responsible, professional work in the research, compilation of data, analysis and studies as described in the Request for Proposals (RFP), for the preparation of a Norcross Master Arts and Cultural Plan. The City is insistent that these documents be user-friendly with adequate visual aids and written in language that is easily understood. The purpose of the Master Arts & Cultural Plan is to develop guidance for the Norcross Public Arts Commission, to identify resources for the support of public art, and cultural programming throughout the City of Norcross, and to set priorities for implementation within Norcross. The proposal shall identify a unified community vision, establish a plan for potential selections and placement of public and cultural art throughout the community, and strive to educate the public about the valuable role public art plays in the community. The proposal shall contain practical policies and be reflective of information that will guide the Norcross Public Arts Commission and City of Norcross in a coordinated and consistent manner to create a more livable and vibrant community."

Trades and Subcontracts: Insulation, Siding, Ceiling, Drywall Bids,MA,Trade Contractors at Risk for the Renovations - Acoustic Ceilings,State/Local,,"Gloucester, Massachusetts","Jun 16, 2022","Gloucester, Massachusetts",https://www.gloucester-ma.gov/bids.aspx?bidID=645,"22109
For Trade Contractors at Risk for the Renovations to the Gloucester Police Station and District Court.

The City of Gloucester seeks proposals from qualified Trade contractors interested in being prequalified for the Renovations to the Gloucester Police Station and District Court. Trade Contractor Statement of Qualifications Forms from interested trade subcontractors are sought for the following categories of work: Masonry, Resilient Flooring, Miscellaneous Metals, Acoustic Ceilings, Waterproofing Damproofing & Caulking, Painting, Metal Windows, Fire Sprinklers, Glass and Glazing, Plumbing Ceramic Tile, Heating, Ventilation & Air Conditioning, Electrical. The RFQ package will be available on April 13, 2022 by emailing purchasing@gloucester-ma.gov or at the Office of the Purchasing Agent.  Proposals must be received and will be opened at Construction Monitoring Services, Inc. 270 Main Street, Marlborough, MA  01752 no later than 11:00 a.m. on May 5, 2022. This Request for Qualifications (“RFQ”) is the first phase of a two-phase procurement process as set forth in MGL Chapter 149A. Only prequalified firms with DCAMM certification will be permitted to submit bids for the above categories.  The City reserves the right to reject any and all proposals or to accept that which is deemed in the best interest of the City of Gloucester, MA.  The City shall not be responsible for proposals arriving late for any reason."

column3: ",Purchasing,,99811,,,"RFP #25-22-1-038, HSIP: Richardson Highway MP 351 Interchange Appraisals

column1: The Northern Region State of Alaska Department of Transportation and Public Facilities (DEPARTMENT), Division of Preconstruction Services, Right of Way Section is soliciting for professional appraisal services for the HSIP: Richardson Highway MP 351 Interchange project.

A complete description of services is contained in the RFP Package.  Estimated period for performance of the Agreement is approximately June 2022 through December 2023.  Cost of these professional services is expected to be in the range of $10,000 and $20,000.

The Request for Proposals (RFP) Package will be available MAY 24, 2022, and may be downloaded from our web site at:  http://www.dot.state.ak.us/procurement/prosvcs/index.shtml; Under Request for Proposals heading, click on “Request for Proposals less than or equal to $200,000”  OR https://dot.alaska.gov/rfpmgr/sm.cfm Or the RFP may be obtained in person from the DOT&PF plans room at the Engineering Services Building, Room 3, 2301 Peger Road, Fairbanks, Alaska.  Persons residing outside the City of Fairbanks may obtain an RFP Package through the mail by telephoning (907) 451-2247 or TDD number 711 or 1-800-770-8973. (for Hearing Impaired, requires special equipment).  There is no charge for the RFP package.

FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS IN THE RFP FOR SUBMITTING PROPOSALS: Proposals must conform to the RFP and be submitted with specified forms.  Submittals must be received at the address indicated on the RFP no later than JUNE 6, 2022, 4:00 p.m., prevailing time.

Currently proposals may be dropped off at our office.  A locked Drop Box is located at the outside entry of the Tech Services Building #3 (Contracts Building Main Parking Lot West Side Entrance).  Call or Text (907) 799-5632 when you place documents in the Drop Box and we will retrieve and timestamp your documents.  Thank you for your understanding and cooperation as we implement social distancing.

Individuals with disabilities, including the hearing impaired, who may need auxiliary aids, services, and/or special modifications to submit a proposal should contact the TTY number 711 or 1-800-770-8973, no later than one week prior to the submittal date to make any necessary arrangements."

Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids,CA,RFP for Appraisal Services,State/Local,,"San Bernardino County Housing Authority, California","Jun 27, 2022","San Bernardino County Housing Authority, California",,"PC1288
column3: ",Purchasing,,909-890-0644,,,"The Housing Authority of the County of San Bernardino (HACSB) is seeking proposals from qualified professional firms or individuals to assist HACSB in Appraisal Services for properties within San Bernardino County, on an on-call basis that may include, but not be limited to, work in the following areas: Residential Appraisal Services (Single Family); and Multi-Family, Commercial and Industrial Appraisal Services.

column1: The purpose of this Request for Proposals (RFP) is to select the most qualified firms for placement on a Roster that will be used to select firms for future assignments. Each firm selected for the Roster will sign an On-Call Contract for Appraisal Services that will not include any specific scope of work. Selected firms shall be able to provide the services described in this RFP within a time frame required by HACSB.

As work assignments arise, HACSB will select a firm from the Roster based upon HACSB’s determination of which firm most closely meets the requirements of the particular assignment taking into account such factors as firm specialization, personnel and availability. HACSB will then notify the firm and negotiate the scope of work and compensation, to be formalized in a Work Order to the On-Call Contract.

The term of the Roster to be created by this RFP shall be five (5) years. In submitting a proposal to be considered for the Roster Program, the firm understands that there is no guarantee of any work or dollar amount under any On-Call Contract resulting from this RFP.
HACSB is soliciting proposals for two (2) categories of real property Appraisal Services. Firms may propose for either or both Categories listed below.
Category 2 – Multi-Family, Commercial and Industrial Appraisal Services

Firms desiring to be considered for placement on the Roster must indicate in their proposal whether they wish to be considered for one or both Categories. The selected firms shall have qualifications and experience to perform the tasks related to the Category of Appraisal Services for which they are applying.

Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids,CA,RFP for Parties of Interest Report (Lien Search),State/Local,,"Sacramento County, California",Today ,"Sacramento County, California",https://dgs.saccounty.gov/capsd/Pages/Current-Bid-Opportunities.aspx,"2022-RFP-0050
column3: ",Purchasing,,916-876-6360,,,"The County of Sacramento is seeking a contractor to provide Parties of Interest (Lien Search) Reports.  This is a countywide contract, but the main users are Community Development Department (Code Enforcement) and the Department of Finance, Tax Collection and Licensing Division. The required reports would be equivalent to a “Litigation Guarantees Report or Trustee Sale Guarantees Report.”  However, the County of Sacramento does not require title insurance and is not requesting a formal Ligation Guarantee or Trustee Sale Guarantee.

column1: The contract resulting from this RFP shall be for an initial two -year period commencing with execution of the contract by the Contract and Purchasing Services.  For reasons of economy and efficiency, the County reserves the right to extend a contract three additional one-year periods, for a total of five years, upon mutual agreement between the County of Sacramento and the contractor.

The Department of Finance, Tax Collector and Licensing requires Party of Interest Reports on a batch of properties prior to their annual tax sales.  Number of reports varies significantly depending on the actual defaults for the annual sale.  The quantity has ranged in from as low as 60 properties up to 400 properties.  The Tax Collector submits these properties in one major batch each year, with the potential of one or more smaller requests at different times of the year.

Code Enforcement requires weekly Party of Interest Reports on properties.  Most requests are single properties, but sometimes include 2 or 3 properties.  Code Enforcement conducts an annual lien hearing, which could include 65 properties.

These volumes listed above are estimates only for planning purposes.  The County may require more or less reports during any contract year and does not guarantee to request a minimum number of reports for any resulting contract.

column1: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids,CA,Bids for GC Services - 1515 South Van Ness,State/Local,,"San Francisco County, California","Jun 15, 2022","San Francisco County, California",https://sfcitypartner.sfgov.org/pages/Events-BS3/event-search.aspx,"0000007053
column3: ",Purchasing,,415-554-6743,,,"Project Summary: The City and County of San Francisco (the “City”), acting through MOHCD and the Sponsors of the parcel at 1515 South Van Ness Avenue (the “Site”) intends to construct an affordable rental housing project including units servicing low-income families, formerly homeless households, low-income people living with HIV, and ground floor commercial use servicing the surrounding neighborhood and the residents at the Site. In November 2020, the City released a Multi-Site Request for Qualifications for Sponsors to work with the City to develop new affordable rental housing projects on nine separate sites, located in various neighborhoods in the City, including this site. Chinatown CDC and Mission Economic Development Agency have been selected by MOHCD as the joint Sponsors for 1515 South Van Ness Avenue.

column1: Scope of Work: General Contractor Services

LBE/SBE Requirement: The project is administered by the San Francisco Mayor’s Office of Housing and Community Development. The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division (CMD) has assigned a 25% SBE participation goal.  The Sponsors are responsible for meeting the overall SBE participation goal, which includes any design and pre-construction services. The selected consultant will be responsible for assisting the Sponsors by providing forms regarding SBE professional services goals as it pertains to their scope of work.
Bid Discount or Rating Bonus: A 10% ratings bonus shall be applied to:

column2: SBE’s proposed as the prime contractor/consultant; or

Joint Ventures as explained here: (1) five percent (5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds thirty-five percent (35%) but is under forty percent (40%); (2) seven and one-half percent (7.5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds forty percent (40%); (3) ten percent (10%) to a SBE prime consultant or a Joint Venture among SBE prime consultants. The Ratings Bonus shall apply to each stage of the selection process, including proposals and interviews. Joint Venture Bid/ratings bonus will be added to the score only to a Joint Venture (1) that meets the requirements contained in the SF SBE Program and (2) when the SBE is an active partner in the Joint Venture, performs work, manages the job, takes financial risks in proportion to the required level of participation stated in the bid documents, is responsible for a clearly defined portion of the work to be performed, and shares proportionately in the Ownership, Control, management responsibilities, risks, and profits of the Joint Venture. The portion of the SBE Joint Venture's work shall be set forth in detail separately from the work to be performed by the non-SBE Joint Venture partner. The SBE Joint Venture's portion of the Contract must be assigned a commercially reasonable dollar value; or

column1: Note: A prime contractor/consultant that is not certified as an SBE that proposes to subcontract to a firm that is certified as an SBE but not as a joint venture will not be awarded a ratings bonus.

Instruction on How to Bid: Please submit one PDF digital copy of proposal by 4:00PM PST on June 15, 2022 to vlira@medasf.org, ldaza@medasf.org, Omar.rahmaoui@chinatowncdc.org, and Angelina.Perez@chinatowncdc.org.

No late submittals will be considered. Note: The maximum MB for emails must remain under 20MB or your submittal may not be received. Please use a link to a secure file sharing system for larger files.

column1: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids,CA,RFP for 772 Pacific GC PreCon/Full Services,State/Local,,"San Francisco County, California","Jun 23, 2022","San Francisco County, California",https://sfcitypartner.sfgov.org/pages/Events-BS3/event-search.aspx,"0000006972
column3: ",Purchasing,,415-554-6743,,,"(1)Project Summary: Following the footsteps of the International Hotel, 772 Pacific will be Chinatown’s first new affordable housing in 20 years. CCDC understands that this project can serve the community with a meaningful commercial program on the ground floor and provide much-needed affordable housing for underserved seniors of all races reflective of the diversity of the City. The major challenge of the project is to achieve a financially feasible residential program on the site’s small footprint. Additionally, it will be important to bring a creative approach to finding a balance between designing a thriving commercial program and re-introducing the cultural heritage of the banquet hall. New Asia is one of the last remaining banquet halls, and it was a popular social, civic, and political gathering hub for over three decades. The design team has the exciting challenge of bringing about a transformative difference to a culturally rich and historic neighborhood.

column1: The developer’s vision for 772 Pacific is to create a mixed-use senior residential community of more than 86 deeply affordable studio and one-bedroom units, subject to SF Planning’s feasibility determination and the project budget that MOHCD approves. We seek to create a high-quality living environment for senior households whose incomes will range between 30% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI up to 60% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI with more than half of the units for seniors with incomes at or below 30% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI. Our development will include on-site property management and resident services, front desk reception at the entry lobby, a community room for programing and events, and a neighborhood-friendly commercial component. As a rare new development, 772 Pacific will provide a tranquil refuge for seniors from Chinatown’s busy streets below while providing an opportunity for seniors to age in place with dignity. Along with the housing, responding to stakeholder input regarding the ground floor commercial use will be an integral part of the work; it is important that the project maximize affordable housing while also continuing to host a community-sustaining ground floor use.

The successful General Contractor firm(s) will demonstrate its ability to participate in a series of meetings with the developer and the design team throughout the design phases to proactively provide input on innovative building components and constructability of design for cost effective, streamlined solutions.
The developer is estimating hard construction cost around $ 60MM, which is subject to change depending on the scale of the building.
Selected General Contractor shall provide input on the following:

column2: The team is interested in exploring emerging construction technologies that will allow the site to be developed in a cost-effective manner while balancing durability and facilitating maintenance.
We will not rule out any system before understanding the cost, site, and staging implications.
Units are stacked for structural efficiency and seismic safety.
Recommendations for efficient residential unit layout and MOD-complying bathroom and kitchen configurations.
Investigate and incorporate building dimensioning to:
Facilitate “zero or reduced waste” during construction,
Facilitate the inclusion of “prefabricated walls and floor areas” that can be “efficiently craned and dropped-in-place” during construction.
Incorporate floor plans and exterior building envelope that can be efficiently built timewise and construction-wise.
Establish an efficient ratio between window area and exterior wall area.
Establish efficient floor-to-floor heights. Building will comply with the all-electric Code requirements.
Plumbing is laid out for efficiency of plumbing runs
Solar power and/or other natural resources to decrease hot water heating and other energy costs
Residential amenities to explore urban agricultural opportunities
In addition to achieving the minimum sustainability standards of TCAC and CDLAC, CCDC is interested in exploring Passive House design standards.
Dos and Don’ts – Lessons learned from other affordable housing and/or MOHCD projects.

column1: For purposes of this RFP, please indicate how long your team believes construction would last for this project. Please refer to the above schedule to inform your construction timeline. The Owner will normalize costs against construction duration among the applicant submissions, so please be mindful that this is an important part of your submission and the Owner’s calculation of your team’s overall fee and general conditions.

column2: *Construction start date subject to external funding NOFA dates & Building permit approval

column1: The Design and Pre-Construction Process involves plan review, cost estimating and value engineering by the Contractor.  The Contractor is expected to actively draw upon their experience, skills, and knowledge to add value to the project during this phase.  During the Design process, the Contractor’s duties will include the pre-construction services outlined in Attachment C: Memorandum of Understanding for Pre-Construction Services.

column2: Attend and participate in regular design meetings, in addition to other meetings as required by Owner;
Conduct exploratory work as necessary or recommended to inform the scope;
Assist the Project team in developing, managing and maintaining a realistic pre-construction schedule with established milestones as well as in developing the construction schedule;

Provide complete project cost estimates, including unit prices, within four weeks following the completion of Concept Design, Schematic Design, Design Development, and at either 50% or 70% Construction Documents phase, and as may otherwise be required;
Review plans and specifications as they are developed throughout the Design period and provide written comments;

Participate in Cost Containment + Green Charette prior to and/or during Concept Design, and value engineering process by proposing design/construction alternatives and by researching the cost implications of design alternatives;
Contribute to the green building design, construction, and compliance process;
Research materials and methods pertaining to the Project;
Secure multiple estimates from subcontractors for all elements of the proposed scope of construction.

Organize and present all sub-contractor bidding information at each cost estimating/bidding stage of the project using a clear and well-organized method, in order to facilitate the development team’s review and understanding of proposed contract pricing.  All bids are to be shared with developer, architect, and its construction representatives. Clear presentation and documentation of pricing and alternative scenarios is of critical importance to the development team.
Conduct scoping exercises and review plans for abatement and demolition work (if required) that will need to be conducted prior to the start of ground-up construction.

column1: (3) LBE/SBE goals for the entire project and specific RFP
Small Business Enterprise Contracting: Subcontracting/Professional Services/Suppliers

The project is administered by the San Francisco Mayor’s Office of Housing and Community Development (MOHCD). The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division has assigned a 20% SBE participation goal for Professional Services.

The Developer and the City strongly desire a contracting team that represents the diversity of the City and, in particular, that of the neighborhood. As such, General Contracting firms certified as DBEs, SBEs, MBEs, WBEs and LBEs are strongly encouraged to reply to this request. Please submit a copy of your DBE, SBE, MBE, WBE or LBE certification.

The selected General Contractor will be required to meet the SBE subcontracting goal of 20% for construction services and comply with the Small Business Enterprise Program rules. Please refer to Attachment A: SBE Program.
Website links for finding Certified DBEs/SBEs/LBEs:
The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division (“CMD”) will confirm that a firm is certified as an SBE under the San Francisco SBE program

Ratings Bonus - The following rating bonus will be in effect for the award of this project for any proposers who are certified as an SBE, or joint ventures where the joint venture partners are in the same discipline and have the specific levels of participation as identified below. The rating bonus applies at each phase of the selection process. The application of the rating bonus is as follows:
• A 10% ratings bonus shall be applied to SBE’s proposed as the prime contractor/consultant; or
• Joint Ventures – A Rating or scoring Bonus will be added to the total proposal score and the total interview score (for firms selected for an interview) in the following breakdown:
(1) five percent (5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds thirty-five percent (35%) but is under forty percent (40%);
(2) seven and one-half percent (7.5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds forty percent (40%);
(3) ten percent (10%) to a SBE prime consultant or a Joint Venture among SBE prime consultants.

The Ratings Bonus shall apply to each stage of the selection process, including proposals and interviews. Joint Venture Bid/ratings bonus will be added to the score only to a Joint Venture (1) that meets the requirements contained in the SF SBE Program and (2) when the SBE is an active partner in the Joint Venture, performs work, manages the job, takes financial risks in proportion to the required level of participation stated in the bid documents, is responsible for a clearly defined portion of the work to be performed, and shares proportionately in the Ownership, Control, management responsibilities, risks, and profits of the Joint Venture. The portion of the SBE Joint Venture's work shall be set forth in detail separately from the work to be performed by the non-SBE Joint Venture partner. The SBE Joint Venture's portion of the Contract must be assigned a commercially reasonable dollar value.
• A prime contractor/consultant that is not certified as an SBE that proposes to subcontract to a firm that is certified as an SBE but not as a joint venture will not be awarded a ratings bonus.

• SBE FORM No. 1 - CONSULTANT/JOINT VENTURE AND SUBCONSULTANT PARTICIPATION REPORT: All proposers are required to complete this form and include the names of the SBEs being used, lower tier SBEs, as well as non-SBEs and a description of the work they will perform, the services or supplies which will be provided by each and the dollar value of each SBE transaction. This completed form must be submitted with the proposal.

• SBE FORM No. 2 - SBE CONSULTANT/JOINT VENTURE PARTNER/SUBCONSULTANT – GROSS REVENUE DECLARATION: An SBE consultant/joint venture partner and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers, including lower tier subconsultants or suppliers, must complete this form AND submit listed firm’s current SBE certification. The prime shall collect the completed forms and submit them with its proposal on the proposal due date. The SBE consultant and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers will need to submit this form declaring, under penalty of perjury, that their total average gross revenues for collect the completed forms and submit them with its proposal on the proposal due date. The SBE consultant and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers will need to submit this form declaring, under penalty of perjury, that their total average gross revenues for the past three years are equal to or below the applicable income thresholds for the specific category of the contract. Refer to the revised SBE FORM 2.

For more information about the San Francisco SBE program as it relates to this solicitation, please see Attachment A and/or contact Selormey Dzikunu; selormey.dzikunu@sfdpw.org at the City and County of San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division.
Deadline for submittal of questions on RFP is due at 4pm on May 17, 2022.

column2: AIA Document A305, Contractor's Qualification Statement

column1: All applicants must complete the AIA A305 Contractor's Qualification Statement or similar formatted form.  The AIA A305 does not need to be notarized.

column2: In responding to Sections 3.4 and 3.5 of the AIA A305, “major construction projects” shall be understood to mean all rehabilitation projects over $5 million and new construction projects over $10 million. In responding to both Section 3.4 (Major Projects in Progress) and Section 3.5 (Major Projects Completed in the Past 3 Years) of the AIA A305, please use the attached form to provide this information (see Attachment G). Identify General Contractor staff involved in each project. Please provide contact information for owner and architect of each project. On a separate sheet or in the A305, please identify projects previously completed that required value engineering and cost estimating services.
In addition, please be aware of and conform to the following requirements, which are separate from those in the AIA A305.  Documentation must be provided for all requirements below:

The contractor shall have been in business for a minimum of three (3) years without any official unresolved record of complaints registered or filed with the Contractor's State License Board of the California Department of Consumer Affairs.

During the past five years, the contractor shall have successfully completed, within time and budgetary constraints, a minimum of two (2) projects of construction type and cost similar to the proposed Project. If the proposed Project represents a Project larger than you have completed, please provide a statement demonstrating your capacity to complete the proposed Project successfully, including meeting bonding requirements.

The contractor shall provide a summary of its current workforce and staffing, and a complete list of projects (including budget and duration) currently under construction, under contract, or in the negotiation stage.

The contractor shall identify employees who will be responsible for providing services on the project, including pre-construction services. Please provide a staffing chart to include all staff who will work and charge to the project in both the pre-construction and construction phases of the project. This could include but is not limited to the Project Executive, Project Manager, Assistant Project Manager, Project Engineer, Pre-Construction Lead, Lead Estimator, and Project Superintendent. Provide resumes for these staff persons. Change to the following identified personnel listed in the RFP response will require Owner’s prior written approval: Lead Estimator, Project Executive, Project Manager, and Superintendent. Please indicate how the contractor will ensure continuity of its institutional knowledge of the project and decision making as the project shifts from pre-construction into bidding and construction, and which staff will continue from the pre-construction phase into the construction phase of the project.

The contractor shall indicate its ability and capacity to perform value engineering and cost estimating services prior to construction while meeting all pre-construction schedule goals.  Please identify projects previously completed that required value engineering and cost estimating services and briefly describe the process and outcomes of specific value engineering efforts, including lessons learned from these projects.  Please identify the name(s) of your staff who will provide the actual cost estimating services for this Project and submit his or her resume.

The contractor shall describe its process for leading the cost estimating and bidding process, and how information regarding sub-contractor bids and pricing is transparently communicated to development team in a comprehensive, well-organized method. An example of how the contractor has developed tools for sharing bidding and pricing information with clients is required.

The contractor shall describe their experience working with the Contractor Monitoring Division and CityBuild or other like/similar economic opportunity programs and provide goals achieved on recent projects for local hire and SBE/LBE/WBE /MBE as they were applied.
The contractor shall describe their experience working with the San Francisco Mayor’s Office on Disability (MOD) or other like/similar inspectors.

The contractor shall describe their knowledge of financing restrictions, particularly the California Tax Credit Allocation Committee (TCAC) requirements that are part of affordable housing project financing. The contractor shall affirmatively state they will work with the Owner to comply with all necessary provisions of TCAC in order for the project to secure financing. This includes proper estimating, scheduling, limiting General Conditions, and providing all necessary warranties. The contractor shall affirmatively state they will accept all provisions of the GMP contract regarding tax credit financing and will work with the Owner to remedy and repair any situation in the course of pre-construction or construction that would put the Owner’s tax credits at risk. The contractor shall affirmatively state they understand that contractor will have to provide documentation of costs after construction has been completed in order for the Owner to secure tax credit financing.
In a separate narrative, detail specific experience with and knowledge of:

New construction mid- to high-rise developments of comparable size and scope in San Francisco and surrounding Bay Area, and any processes, systems and/or materials that are particular to this type of residential construction. If no prior San Francisco experience, please describe Contractor’s experience and solutions to working on challenging urban infill projects, and how these projects may apply to this specific Project site.

Working with a client, such as CCDC, that has an array of stakeholders that have input on decisions, including construction related changes, VE, etc. For example, CCDC often has to inform and receive direction from other departments within the firm for programmatic changes that can lead to longer timeframes for decision-making.

“Green” building construction and complying with and/or exceeding Green Point Rated construction criteria or other like programs (LEED, Passive House, etc). Please provide a brief description of any experience with Passive House and assessment of applicability for 772 Pacific.

Equitable hiring and promotion practices. Please detail how your firm is working to ensure that women and people of color are represented at all levels of your organization, as well as supporting the advancement of women and people of color in project management and construction.
Please provide a brief description of experience with emerging construction technologies and their assessment of potential applicability to 772 Pacific.
Please describe experience with design-build and/or design-assist MEP and speak to the initial assessment of efficacy for 772 Pacific.

column1: All applicants must submit a fee, general conditions, and general requirements proposal. Applicants should use an estimated hard construction cost of $60 million and place duration information and general conditions into the template included in Attachment H (additional lines may be added). All estimated construction cost and duration are preliminary for fee proposal purposes only and subject to change.

column2: A proposed fee (based on a percentage) for the estimated construction contract amount of $60 million, which does not include overhead and profit.

Itemized general conditions costs based on the aforementioned contract amount. For the purposes of calculating the general condition costs, applicants should propose a construction duration in which they believe they can successfully complete construction of the Project, excluding demolition which will be placed under a separate contract.
Itemized/proposed general requirements, with line item breakout, must be provided.
Proposed fees for general conditions, overhead and profit must not exceed the TCAC, HCD, and City of San Francisco maximum allowable fees.
Please note: MOHCD has indicated they will not accept proposed GC held Contingencies over 5%.
A sample from a recent, comparable project of each of the following:
Cost estimate, including closing construction contract amount and construction cost at completion
Plan review comments from a CD progress set of documents
Acceptance of the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding & Proposed Construction Contract

column1: The contractor shall affirmatively state their acceptance of all terms of the proposed Memorandum of Understanding and proposed Construction Contract (to be provided by 5/25/2022) or identify specific terms to which they take exception. This affirmative statement or list of contract terms must be included with the contractor’s proposal.
The short-listed contractors will be evaluated on the basis on the fee proposal, submitted documents, interview by the selection panel and reference calls made in this phase.

Following the interviews and reference calls, the highest-scoring/ranking applicant will be conditionally selected for the purposes of negotiating a Memorandum of Understanding (see Attachment C) for pre-construction services with expectation to contract for construction.

This section outlines the terms and conditions which will be set forth in the construction contract.  In submitting the contractor qualifications, the contractor acknowledges that he/she has read and understands that these terms and conditions apply to the Project.  Owner reserves the right to revise and/or add any terms and conditions beyond those set forth below.

The Contractor will be required to post payment and performance bonds in an amount equal to 100% of the construction contract.  The bond issuer shall be listed in U.S. Treasury Department Circular No. 570.  The Contractor shall obtain and maintain Worker's Compensation Insurance to the extent required by law.  The Contractor shall maintain General Liability Insurance in accordance with the MOHCD requirements as found in Attachment I. Please note that while Attachment I references HUD, this is not a HUD project. The project will most likely have an Owner-Controlled Insurance Program (OCIP), please see Attachment J.

column1: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids,NJ,RFQ for Construction Monitoring Services - Replacement of Electrical Cables and  Subway Structure Renovation,State/Local,,"Delaware River Port Authority, New Jersey","Jun 8, 2022","Delaware River Port Authority, New Jersey",https://www.drpa.org/procurement/upcoming-purchases-and-bids.asp?param=2&num=9036,"RFQ
column3: ",Purchasing,,856-772-6914,,,"The DRPA hereby invites interested professional consulting engineering firms to submit a Statement of Qualification (“SOQ”) for Construction Monitoring Services in connection with Contract No. 10-K, PATCO Replacement of Electrical Cables and  Subway Structure Renovation.  This public advertisement constitutes the DRPA’s formal solicitation to determine the interest of qualified firms in the Project.

column1: The Scope of Services the Authority requires shall include construction monitoring services for the replacement and elimination of various power, signal, and communications cables running primarily within the Philadelphia tunnel of the PATCO system as well as traction-power equipment within Locust Street Substation, located in the area of the PATCO tunnel, below the concourse level and directly under Locust Street, immediately west of Broad Street, in Philadelphia.  The interested Construction Monitoring firm shall be note that the equipment replacements at Locust Street Substation represent a significant logistical challenge and that the firm will need to coordinate the work with PATCO and the Contractor to be completed successfully and without significant disruptions to PATCO’s operations.  Multi-pair copper communications cable, the use of which has diminished significantly over the years at PATCO, will be eliminated, and any communications currently carried over copper cables will be moved to existing fiber optics.  The use of multi-conductor signal cable will be reduced by converting relay-based vital signaling to microprocessor-based vital signaling, placing signal communications between instrument locations onto existing fiber optics.  In addition to electrical portion of the project, the firm will also be involved with monitoring structural repairs to PATCO’s Philadelphia tunnel.  Work will involve concrete repairs, type 1 and 2 spall repairs, crack injections, steel repairs, steel painting, and column repairs.  The electrical and structural portions of this project will be performed in PATCO’s Philadelphia subway tunnel which runs 1.75 miles from 17th and Locust streets to the Front Street substation beneath the Benjamin Franklin Bridge."

Firm, or Corporation, herein “Respondent”, to provide as-needed easement and right of way
Typically, a City Project Manager will identify the need for such services in the course of engineering

guidelines established under the Federal Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property

column3: ",Purchasing,,707-565-2433,,,"The County of Sonoma is pleased to invite you to respond to a Request for Proposals for Employment Related Investigative Services.

column1: The County seeks competitive proposals for employment-related investigative and consulting services, and will establish contracts with those proposers that the County determines are best qualified and most appropriate to serve the County on an “as needed” basis. The services required consist of performing internal investigations and related work that may cover a broad range of issues, including but not limited to equal employment opportunity (EEO), discipline, and liability. In an effort to facilitate County access to specialized investigative services for various types of employment investigations, master agreements with multiple contractors will be implemented. Workers’ compensation investigations are not included in the scope of this RFP.
For questions regarding this specific solicitation, email victoria.willard@sonoma-county.org."

column3: ",Purchasing,,,ctalmadge@fayetteville-ga.gov,,"Request for Proposal RFP Item # WS505-05 Utility Bill Printing and Mailing Services The City of Fayetteville, Georgia RFP Due: Thursday, June 09, 2022 @ 200 P.M. Question Deadline: Tuesday, May 31, 2022 @ 5:00 P.M. The City of Fayetteville is requesting sealed proposals from qualified firms for Utility Bill Printing and Mailing services. All proposals shall be submitted to the Office of Finance & Administrative Services, located at 210 Stonewall Avenue W, Fayetteville, Georgia, 30214 until 2:00 P.M., Thursday, June 09, 2022 at which time, proposals will be opened and publicly read. The City Council reserves the right to reject any and all proposals and to waive formalities. Instructions for preparation and submission of the proposal are contained on the City of Fayetteville’s website, https://fayetteville-ga.gov/government/bids-and-rfps/active-solicitations/. Any changes to the conditions and specifications for this RFP must be in the form of a written addendum to be valid; therefore, the City will issue a written addendum to document all approved changes. Any proposal submitted which does not acknowledge the receipt of an addendum will not be considered. Should you have any questions concerning the proposal documents, or need additional information, you may contact Carleetha Talmadge, our City’s Designated Contact, directly at 770-719-4161 or by email at ctalmadge@fayetteville-ga.gov. Mailing Address for package submission: Carleetha Talmadge – Assistant Director of Finance & Administrative Services 210 Stonewall Avenue W Fayetteville, GA 30214 RFP Response – RFP #WS505-05 Utility Bill Printing and Mailing Services for City of Fayetteville"

The Houston-Galveston Area Council, the fiscal agent for the Gulf Coast Workforce Board, is issuing this Solicitation on behalf of the Board and Workforce Solutions and is seeking a qualified contractor to perform professional services for the Workforce Solutions system. Any subsequent contract awarded under this solicitation will be executed with the Houston-Galveston Area Council as the contracting entity.

Workforce Solutions has a central Financial Aid Payment Office responsible for handling vendor billing and payments for our customer’s financial aid. The Financial Aid Payment Office works with our system’s vendors by initiating vendor agreements and making billing and payment arrangements. This includes payments to childcare vendors, training providers, and support service vendors as well as payments to employers for on-the- job training reimbursements and custom training projects.
Respondents that propose to operate Financial Aid Payment Office may not propose to operate the Financial Aid Support Office."

column3: ",Purchasing,,209-525-7640,,,"The County of Stanislaus (County) is seeking proposals from qualified and experienced organizations for the provision of Emergency Management Training on behalf of the County’s Office of Emergency Services (OES), located at 3705 Oakdale Rd., Modesto CA 95357.

column1: The Stanislaus County Office of Emergency Services (OES), in compliance with the National Incident Management System (NIMS), Standardized Emergency Management System (SEMS), and Incident Command System (ICS), provides emergency management training to a diverse audience, including, but not limited to, emergency response personnel, government employees, disaster service workers and volunteers, non-government organizations, and private businesses. Training is provided at various levels to Boards of Supervisors, City Councils, elected officials, command and general staff, emergency managers, and emergency operations center management team members. Training may move staff toward meeting requirements of the National Qualification System (NQS) and the California Governor’s Office of Emergency Services (Cal OES) Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Position Credentialing Program.

column1: Consulting: Emergency Preparedness, Disaster, Recovery, and Security Assessment Bids,CA,RFP for Consultant Services to Develop a Security Strategy,State/Local,,"San Diego, California","Jun 17, 2022","San Diego, California",,"10089843-22-B
column3: ",Purchasing,,619-236-6000,,,"The City of San Diego, Office of Emergency Services Department (“City”), is seeking a Consultant to update the current security strategy. The selected contractor will develop a plan to update the 2017-2019 San Diego Urban Area (SDUA) Homeland Security Strategy, hereafter referred to as the “Strategy”. While the current Strategy may be used as a starting point and baseline guide for the update of this Strategy, this revised Strategy will more effectively and efficiently utilize the region’s latest Threat and Hazard identification and Risk Assessment (THIRA) and Stakeholder Preparedness Report (SPR) as a central and consistent focus throughout the document. This focused method has not been included in previous updates to the Strategy.

column1: The THIRA and SPR are the only two region-wide threat and hazard related products that are developed by City of San Diego Office of Emergency Services (OES) and required by Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for periodic completion and submission, to DHS. Their use and incorporation in the development of this update to the Strategy is now emphasized and intended to ensure greater consistency in addressing and implementing regional threat and hazard priorities. This conscious and active use of the THIRA/SPR to inform the Strategy will also ensure that the regional estimates, impacts, outcomes and evaluation based on the FEMA core capabilities that these documents describe and project are more consistently reflected in the Strategy, and as a result of collaboration and coordination among the region’s homeland security stakeholders. The selected contractor will also continue to incorporate, as necessary, the risk analysis tools that have been used previously in the development of the Strategy (e.g., Cal COP products, liaison with appropriate LECC staff, and use of specialized OES maintained data bases that can all provide important inputs to the Strategy (e.g., SEAR and CIKR databases used and accessed by OES).

Consulting: Emergency Preparedness, Disaster, Recovery, and Security Assessment Bids,TX,Post Hurricane / Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment,State/Local,,State of Texas 2,"Jun 23, 2022",State of Texas 2,http://www.txsmartbuy.com/esbddetails/view/1452A2,"1452A2
column3: ",,,,mforbes@co.cameron.tx.us,,"Post Hurricane / Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment

column1: Cameron County requests qualifications from engineering, architectural and consulting firms (collectively, Consultants) interested in providing professional services to conduct post-hurricane/disaster damage assessment as part of the County’s overall Post-Hurricane Recovery Operations.  The County recognizes that immediately after a major disaster, local firms might not be able to respond quickly to a request for services.  As a result, the County is interested in contracting with firms both in the local area and outside the local area to ensure that an adequate resource base is available regardless of the extent of damage within the County.  This contract shall cover calendar years 2022 through 2027.

The concept for post-hurricane recovery operations is for the County to have a number of pre-event contracts in place that will provide personnel to assist local government staffs with damage assessment activities immediately after a hurricane or other disaster.  Damage Assessment Teams (DATs) will be comprised of government and Consultant personnel under the overall direction of Cameron County staff.  The work will entail preliminary assessment and documentation of the scope and nature of damage incurred throughout the County in accordance with direction and guidance provided by the County.  The work will also include detailed documentation of damage to public property and facilities.  The work may also include assistance with repair plans and specifications and/or assistance with monitoring contractors involved in emergency protective measures.  The County will provide necessary training on the assessment process and completion of the associated forms and records.

It is the County's intent to identify qualified Consultant firms, enter into an agreement with each qualified firm, and be able to activate as many firms as necessary to provide prompt damage assessment services immediately following a hurricane or other disasters. The unpredictable nature of hurricanes or other disasters precludes providing more detailed descriptions of the actual work assignments at this time.

The primary focus of the pre-positioned contracts is post-hurricane and other /disaster recovery operations.  Notwithstanding, the County may activate the same contracts for response to any disaster, natural or man-made, regardless of the scope of damage.  The County may contact any of the Consultants under contract at any time for assistance in this area.  The intent is that the firm will provide personnel to the extent of their capabilities at the time of the request.  Submitters should consider this concept."

column3: ",Individual Contacts,,802-828-2211,cgrant@townofmiddlebury.org,,"Local Hazard Mitigation Planning Services for the Town of Middlebury

column1: The Town of Middlebury is seeking proposals for services of a qualified consultant to create a new Local Hazard Mitigation Plan for the Town. The plan will be submitted to FEMA for approval. The selected consultant must be available and willing to complete the required work within 18-months of the date of the award of the contract, including FEMA approval. It is expected that the FEMA grant will cover consultant expenses, accounting for 75% of the project, with the Town of Middlebury responsible for the remaining 25%, monetarily and in-kind hours. The available amount for consultant expense is capped at $7,612.50. The project proposal should be in line wit the FEMA Review Tool (see full RFP for details). Qualified, interested individuals should submit the following information no later than June 1, 2022 at 4:00 p.m.: 1. Consultant’s qualifications and resume. Consultant should be able to identify various hazard mitigation strategies that will eliminate or greatly reduce the impact of hazards that may affect the municipality and have experience related to mitigation planning work. 2. Description of experience with grant-funded projects, especially FEMA or Vermont Emergency Management programs. 3. Project and cost proposal, itemized by project steps as identified above. Proposal should include all consultant hourly rates and any associated direct expenses. The Town of Middlebury encourages responses from disadvantaged, women-owned, minority-owned and small local firms. Selected candidates should be prepared to execute a contract that contains pass-through provisions regarding Federal programs and assurance related to this grant-funded work, including policies regarding conflicts of interest, equal opportunity, non-discrimination, retention of and access to records, and audit requirements, when applicable. The Town of Middlebury reserves the right to reject any or all responses. Responses and inquires should be sent to: Crystal Grant, cgrant@townofmiddlebury.org For full RFP, visit www.townofmiddlebury.org > Town Notices > at bottom of page, see Bid Advertisements.

column3: ",Purchasing,,757-664-4787,,,"The City of Norfolk (the “City”) invites proposals from qualified firms for a series of exercises that will help guide the cities of Norfolk, Chesapeake, Newport News, Virginia Beach, and Hampton towards better coordination during critical incidents that cross jurisdictional boundaries. column5: ",Purchasing,,703-695-7145,devin.green.5@us.af.mil,,"***THIS IS A SOURCES SOUGHT NOTICE ONLY; NOT A REQUEST FOR QUOTE (RFQ)*** The 188th WG Arkansas Air National Guard is seeking contractors interested in providing resort services for a Strong Bonds Marriage Enrichment event in the Downtown area of Hot Springs, AR on Friday, 26 August to Sunday, 28 August, 2022. The venue should be able to accommodate up to eighteen (18) couples plus three (3) support staff & one (1) therapy dog; totaling twenty (20) rooms for two (2) days. In addition, the venue should have an appropriate meeting space that can seat the capacity with the ability to spread couples out far enough so discussions are not overheard. This meeting space must be available for all three days of the retreat (Friday evening, Saturday morning & afternoon, & Sunday morning). The meeting space should also include any audio-visual equipment, Wi-Fi, & drinks (i.e. water, coffee, tea, soda). The venue should be able to cater the following meals; premium Friday dinner, standard hot breakfast buffet on Saturday & Sunday, & standard hot buffet lunch on Saturday.? The venue should be in close proximity to the Downtown area of Hot Springs, AR & include the following on-site amenities; restaurant, catering, bar, spa, & meeting rooms. This Sources Sought notice is being issued in accordance with Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) Part 10, Market Research. Its sole purpose is to provide information for planning & market research purposes only & shall not be construed as either a solicitation or obligation on the part of the 188th WG. The purpose of this Sources Sought is to help the 188th WG understand industry best practices, technical solutions, & sources capable of meeting the requirements. The 188th WG welcomes responses from all Small Business interested parties; however, no decision or award of contract will be made on the basis of responses from industry. The 188th WG will not pay for the preparation of, nor the subsequent use of, information submitted in response to this Sources Sought. Respondents will not be notified of the outcome of the 188th WG's review of the information received. Additionally, the 188th WG does not intend to hold discussions concerning this with any interested parties, but reserves the right to contact vendors if additional information is required for clarifications as it pertains to this Sources Sought. All interested vendors will provide the 188th WG, in writing, a notice stating their positive intention to submit a quote, if & when a formal solicitation is issued. Please provide your business size/Small Business status, CAGE Code, & Unique Entity Identifier (UEI) when responding to this notice. Interested vendors must be SAM registered & information shall be provided via email to 188.WG.Contracting.Org@us.af.mil with the following subject line; ""Sources Sought - F6Q0FW2137AW01"" Potential offerors may provide a list of capabilities. Response must be received by Wednesday, 08 June, 2022, 12:00 PM Central Time."

column5: ",,,502-573-2350,arnold_casterline@ao.uscourts.gov,,"This is a solicitation prepared in accordance with Judiciary Guide Volume 14, ?325.30 Soliciting Under Small Purchase Procedure. This requirement is for Hotel/Lodging for 2022 FDPRC Authorized Case Training I (ACT I). This requirement is unrestricted. The Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts (AO) is seeking hotel/lodging venue for the 2022 FDPRC Authorized Case Training I (ACT I) in? Miami, FL. The event is planned for March 02, 2022 to March 06, 2022. ? Please refer to the attached solicitation document USCA22Q0018 and Attachment 1- Hotel Quote.
